August 23rd, 1937.

Dear Father Mackey,

I am letting you know that Louie is quite well and has gained in weight since he came home. But sorry to say that Louis will not be going back to Shubenacadie school any more. I can send him to school here; it is only about two minutes walk from our house and he can go to school and be good company for his sister Clara at nights. Has Mathew and I have a chance to work in the woods all this winter and by keeping Louie home it will save me the trouble of hiring someone to stay with Clara. We have a nice little home and there is nothing to hinder me from keeping my family together from now on which they haven't had for some time. They think a lot of one another and there will not be any need of separating them any more. When I can give him the same schooling here as he can get at Shubenacadie and it will also save you a lot of trouble and there is no use of me writing to the Indian agent at Fredericton as he never answers my letters anyway. But if you think that should write to the department and explain to them I will do so but I wish to hear from you first so please write.

Yours truly,

Mr. Frank Thomas (SIGNED)

Shubenacadie, N.S.

OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

Reference your letter file 51-0-10, regarding children whose "Application for Admission" forms were returned to me, I wish to report on each one individually as follows:

STEPHEN LABOBE; 14 years of age. Parents very poor. Lives about 1½ miles from Day School. Parents seem unable to influence him to attend School here.

ABRAM PETERS; 9 years of age. Parents extremely poor in this case, and are of an unsettled nature. Practically no permanent home.

LAURA JACOBS; 6 Years. Parents both deceased. Lives with Mrs. Thaddie Knockwood who is a distant relative. Lives about 1½ miles from Day School.

JOSEPHINE THOMAS; 11 Years of age. Living with Mrs. Madeline Francis who is her aunt, and who is very poor and unable to manage this girl.

ALBERT FRANCIS; 8 Years of age. Refuses to attend School owing to a grievance between his parents and the Day School teacher, which has been in existence a long time. John Francis father of this boy is very anxious for him to receive a good education.
DAVID KNOCKWOOD: 14 years of age. This a grown up boy, and the father not living at home, he is rather uncontrollable at home and it is difficult to get him to attend the Day School. The mother is anxious to have him receive a couple more years in the Residential School where he can be disciplined.

JOSEPH LEWIS: 14 years of age. This a bright boy, and parents do not pull together, the father contending that he should remain at home and work, while the mother wishes him to attend school. The boy himself is very very disappointed that he cannot attend school 100 per cent. I feel that his admission to the Residential School would be the only solution.

RAYMOND LEWIS: 6 years of age. Just a young bit of a boy and parents live about 1½ miles from school. Cannot possibly attend school in winter time.

WILLIAM COPAGE: 6 years of age. Lives on Scotchfort Reserve where there is no Indian Day School. Refused admission to the local Provincial School. May say this boy has a brother and sister now attending the Residential School.

Trusting this report will be favorable enough to warrant the admission of these children to Residential School, should there be sufficient accommodation for them.

Your obedient servant

"With reference to children who attend the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, there is one named Ida Ginish, daughter of John Ginish of the Burton Church Reserve, who is 15 years of age and her father wishes her to remain at home to help him keep house and take care of her little brother. I have let her remain at home until I hear from you as to whether she can remain home or not.

"In regard to the above case I would think it reasonable to let this girl remain with her father, as he has a good comfortable home but no one to take care of it as his wife is dead. Ida Ginish is a big strong girl for her age, and appears to know all about keeping house. She has been at the Shubenacadie school for five years. I would be pleased to have your view of this matter as soon as convenient."

Dear Sir,

While at Malagawatch Reserve a few days ago, I was interviewed by Mr. Tom Joe regarding the three children of William Henney who are cared for by Mr. Joe's mother, Widow Maggie Joe.

Some years ago, the mother of these children died and since then they have been cared for by the grandmother, the above mentioned Widow Maggie Joe, and received an allowance of $8.00 per month for such care. Mr. Joe stated that now as his mother is very old and there is no other woman in the house, it is very hard for them to look after them properly.

The father, William Henney, who is a roamer and although he belongs to Malagawatch and owns a little shack there, wishes to take the children with him and have the shack repaired at the Department's cost. Without a woman in his house I cannot see how he can care for the children, even if he would settle home and give up his continual travelling. As he is opposed to having the children placed elsewhere, I beg to ask if I can place them in proper homes, even if the father opposed this? He did not care for them since many years and I have very little faith in his future actions in this respect. Can the boy be sent to the Residential school at Shubenacadie without the father's consent but with the consent of the guardian? There is no space available for girls, at that school, at present, but I can get proper homes for them if I may do so.

Yours truly,

Truney - Indian School, Shubenacadie, N.S.

5-1-38

1. The late P.M. of this date Father Mackie, of the Schubnacadie School, came to this Detachment office and reported that one, Noel JULIAN had run away from school some time between 7:00 and 7:30 P.M. Father Mackie gave me a description of the boy and stated that the boy's home was near Antigonish on the Heatherton Reserve.

2. I immediately called Truro Detachment giving them all available information.

3. Father Mackie patrolled to Stewiacke in his car and local enquiries were instigated here.

4. A few hours later Father Mackie reported to me the boy had stopped in at East Stewiacke but immediately left when the owner of the house telephoned in. Father Mackie requested my assistance in going to Stewiacke to locate the boy.

5. I accompanied Father Mackie to Stewiacke in his car. Chief of Police Taylor had taken the boy into custody prior to our arrival.

6. Noel JULIAN was escorted back to the Indian School at Shubenacadie.

No Expenses Incurred.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 14th instant in regard to the discharge of Eileen Gallant. This child has always had a weak constitution, and about two weeks ago, she caught the "flu" which quickly developed into pneumonia. The T.B. test by the Public Health Doctor was given a few days before that. At the time we did not have any "flu" cases. However, Eileen Gallant has quite recovered and we suppose that within a month, she will be back to normal health again. A letter from her mother some time ago gave the impression that the girl is no longer considered a ward of the Department.

When the Doctor says that she is back to normal again, we will let you know.

Yours very truly,

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant with reference to the request of Freeman Knockwood for the re-admission to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School of one of his boys.

Your letter of October 27, 1937 read in part as follows:

"The other case was that of the children of Freeman Knockwood. This man had begged me to get his children into the School. Now because of some foolish tales told by his children he was reluctant to return them. However, after the police had acted in the other case, this man finally consented to send the children on the condition that I forward to you a request that he be allowed to have his children back home. The plea is that their mother wants them to help her whilst he is away working. I must confess that this family is one of the best as regards cleanliness and behaviour. However, you and Father Mackey must decide this question as to the return of these two (or one) Indian children to their home."

In view of the last part of your letter the Department felt that you were not opposed to the discharge of these children and as Father Mackey appeared glad to get rid of them from the school we approved their discharge.

Rev. W. V. McCarthy,
Indian Agent,

20-5-38

1. The P.M. of this date Father Mackey of the Indian School, Shubenacadie, N.S., reported that two Indian boys, Clarence CLOUD and Leo Toney, subject of separate reports, had left the Institution some time during the Late P.M. of the 19-5-38 or Early A.M. of the 20-5-38.

2. I notified Truro Detachment giving them a description of the two boys and then accompanied by Father Mackey patrolled to Stewiacke in P/C CODE, here I notified Chief of Police Taylor and watched the train for the runaways, and then continued along No. 2 Highway until I met the Truro patrol.

3. I returned to Shubenacadie and made a patrol to Elmsdale in P/C CODE 1691 making enquiries at Canteens along the road.

22-5-38

4. The P.M. of this date I received a telephone message from Mr. MacDonald of Cooks Brook that two boys were in the vicinity of Cooks' Brook and had attempted to break into the premises of Chas. Blades. Mr. MacDonald stated they looked like Indians.

I notified Father Mackey and then accompanied him in his car patrolled to Cooks' brook where we located the boys. I examined the Blades house but could see no signs of any violence used on any of the doors or windows. All windows appeared to be securely fastened.

The boys were escorted back to Shubenacadie by the car.

An extra copy of this report forwarded direct to Inspector Truro Detachment for his information and file.

No Expenses Incurred.

In reply I beg to state that the reason for asking that he be sent to the residential school, is that the parents of this child do not live together and his mother neglects him entirely, and it does not seem that anything can be done to remedy this situation. I have tried every means at my command to have these people live peaceable and look after their children but it simply cannot be done. This boy's mother is away nearly all the time, and his father is no good to look after him and he does not attend the school half of the time. I would recommend that this a bonafide case for the residential school. I might state that there is no accommodation at the Shubenacadie school until after July 1st.

Dear Sir:

I wish to ask you to permit Martha Simon, of the Big Cove Reserve who is attending the Shubenacadie Residential school, to go home at the end of this term, June 30th. The reason that I ask this, is that her mother is in much need of assistance in their home. This girl is only 14 years of age and has attended the Shubenacadie school for 6 years, but under the circumstances I have to recommend that if possible she be allowed to go home.

The circumstances are like this, Martha's eldest sister who helps her mother, is now married and her husband has quite a good home but she won't leave home until Martha goes home, and this is the cause of many quarrels between this young couple. Mrs. Simon, Martha's mother, has 7 other children, one only 1 month old, so it appears as if it were necessary that this girl is needed to help her mother.

I should have written you before about this case as I promised these people to do so, but I overlooked the matter until today.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th instant enclosing applications and certificates of health for the admission of Michael Silliboy and John Googoo to the Shubenacadie Residential School. It is noted that in the case of the former his mother is dead and that in regard to the latter both parents are dead. The Department has no objection to their admission to the Shubenacadie School provided the Principal is able to provide accommodation for them. You should communicate with him and ascertain if he is willing to accept them. In the event of their going to the school I do not see any reason for an escort as they can be placed in charge of the train officials. Payment of their transportation will be paid on receipt from you of a properly certified account in triplicate.

If you receive word from Father Mackey that he will take them you may purchase the clothing that they require for going to the school but no unnecessary expense should be incurred in this regard.

Dear Sir:

Lillian Polchies, eleven year old orphan girl, who for the past month has been a patient in the St. Joseph's Hospital at St. John, N.B., where she has undergone several operations for osteomylitis has been discharged from the hospital. I had her returned to St. Vincent's Convent where she was before entering the hospital.

I would like to add here that Dr. G. M. Kelly, spared neither time or effort and much work, he did not even ask compensation for, but he is delighted as I am that this little life has been saved.

Dear Mr. MacCutcheon:

Inclosed please find statement of account for the month of July. You will note that from July 15 to July 27, no attendance was required. Unfortunately at that time our Lillian developed an abscess on the left arm and it had to be treated.

Your favor of July 28, has just reached me. I am having the Physical Examination reports filled in, and returned to you at once. I would be very glad indeed if Lillian were returned to St. Vincent's for a time at least. We could keep in touch with her condition, and then of course Lillian has many personal friends at the Orphanage.

I want to thank you again, Mr. MacCutcheon for your kindly reference to me. All through this long tedious case your attitude has made our work just a pleasure. I am sure you will do your best to keep Lillian here for a time.

As I am planning to leave St. John early tomorrow Saturday July 30, I want to get the reports away to you without delay.

I hope that what we have been doing will be satisfactory to you. We are still hoping to meet you and to thank you personally for so many kindnesses to us.

Sincerely,

[Signature]
Dr. C. M. Kelly

Please return to me

MacCutcheon

Dear Sir,

Dear Mr. Spinney:

Your letter to the Department concerning the return of registered pupils, and the coming of seven new ones, has been referred to me.

As for the children returning from vacation, it was understood that the parents pay the return fare. Most Agents have made it a point to have the return fare from the parents before they would recommend that the children go home for vacation. If you have done this then there should be no difficulty about the ones returning from vacation. If you are not in that position and the parents will not produce the fare, then you pay their way here and we will return the amount to you.

Concerning the new ones, the Department has in the past paid their fare, so you pay it, and send your accounts in triplicate to the Department. As for clothing, get as little as possible for them, and send the account in with the ordinary accounts for food, etc.

The single fare for most of these children -- I believe the majority are under twelve years of age -- should not exceed fifty-five or sixty cents. For those over twelve, it will be just double. I don't think you could bring them by car for less than that. Needless to say that if the parents of those who are home for vacation, do not pay the return fare, these same children will not go home for vacation next year.

Hoping that you will be able to arrange things satisfactorily,

Yours very truly,

21-9-38.

1. This date Father Mackey in charge of the Indian School Shubenacadie, reported the disappearance of two Indian boys, Gregory DENNY and Steven Labobe (see separate report) from the school just after dark.

2. A description of the boys was taken and immediately telephoned to the Truro Detachment and the Chief of Police in Stewiacke.

3. A patrol was then made accompanied by L/Cpl Cheesman and Father Mackey in Father Mackey's car of the Shubenacadie and Stewiacke districts. No trace of the boys could be found.

23-9-38.

4. It was reported to Father Mackey that half a loaf of bread had been stolen a few miles out the Maitland Road, and it is felt that the boys went out in that direction. This date accompanying L/Cpl Cheesman in P/C Code 1691 while on other duties a patrol was made out the Maitland Road and a sharp watch was kept for the boys and enquiries were made but there was no trace of them.

5. A strict lookout will be kept for these boys and enquiries will be continued.

File References Re: Gregory DENNY - Truancy, Indian School, Shubenacadie, Hants Co., N.S.

6-10-38

1. This date Father Ernest Chisson, Thorburn, N.S.; Indian Agent for Pictou Reserve, found Gregory DENNY, subject of this file, hiding in the woods near the Pictou Reserve and returned him personally to the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, N.S.

7-10-38

2. At 9:00 A.M. this date, Father J.F. Mackey, Principal of the Indian School, telephoned this Detachment, stating that DENNY had disappeared again and requested that the member of this Detachment assist in locating him. It was thought DENNY had gone towards South Maitland, Hants Co., N.S. An immediate patrol was made to Admiral Rock and district and although DENNY had been observed by one or two persons around 9:30 A.M., he could not be located. Truro Detachment was notified by telephone to watch northbound trains, particularly the D.A.R.Y and given a verbal description of the boy.

8-10-38

3. This date, accompanied by Father Mackey, a patrol was made to Princeport, Col. Co., via the Indian School car where it was learned that DENNY had succeeded in obtaining a ride on the 6:40 P.M. D.A.R.Y passenger train, bound for Truro. The previous evening, the patrol continued to Truro. Cst. Morgan, who checked incoming trains on the evening of the 7-10-38 stated he had not seen DENNY. It is believed DENNY jumped from the train before its arrival at the Depot. Chief Fraser, Truro Town Police, was notified and also given a description of subject. The patrol continued to New Glasgow and the N.C.O. 1/6 that detachment informed of DENNY's escape. Father Chisson, Indian Agent, was contacted and a patrol made to the Pictou Reserve to see if DENNY could be found. Father Chisson however learned that DENNY prior to being apprehended, had informed two other Indian boys at the reserve, that if caught he intended heading for the State of Maine, U.S.A., to pick potatoes - the next time he escaped! (sheriff Detachment was notified by telephone and a verbal description of subject given.

12-10-38

4. This date Father Chisson located DENNY in woods near Pictou Reserve and again escorted him back to the Indian School, Shubenacadie.

15-10-38

5. At 4:30 P.M. this date Father Mackey telephoned this Detachment stating DENNY had run away again, in company with one Noel JULIAN, age 14 (see separate report), also an inmate of the School. He seemed to believe the boys were heading for Truro. Truro Detachment was notified immediately by telephone.

6. The investigation will continue and a further report submitted to comply with diary date.

Dear Father Johnston:

We had a letter from the Department of Indian Affairs as to taking Russel McLeod. We will take him any time, and we hope that you will come along with him. Also bring his Baptismal Certificate. As for his clothing, don't go to any expense; we will fix him up here.

Richard POULETTE (Indian)
Escaped from Indian School,
Shubenacadie, Hants County, N.S.
(Assistance to Shubenacadie Detachment)

10-11-38

1. This date, a telephone call was received from the N.C.O., I/C Shubenacadie Detachment, requesting a watch be had for two escaped Indian Boys from the above noted school. Richard POULETTE, age 15 years, clothes No. 74, wearing leather cap. Noel JULIAN, age 14 years, clothes No. 139, hair shaved off. Last seen boarding train for Truro but departed from train enroute. Boys escaped shortly after dark.

2. The writer, whilst on Traffic Patrol Duty, Truro to Brookfield Districts failed to locate escaped boys on highway. Information was received that the boys were seen walking highway toward Truro. Upon returning to Truro, at about 9:30 p.m., started to search Sydney Train believing that these boys would hoboes their way on the train. Within a short time observed five hoboes standing near engine of train mentioned. I managed to apprehend subject who failed to notice my approach but JULIAN the other escaped Indian made good his departure, due to him being considerable distance from POULETTE.

3. Subject was placed in the County Jail Truro, to await escort from Indian School.

NO.P.C.R.

4. A further search was carried out for Julian but without success. Truro Town Police notified on same.

11-11-38

5. This date, L/Cpl. Chessman arrived in Truro, escorted subject from Jail for Indian School.

6. Extra copy of this report for the information of the N.C.O., I/C Shubenacadie Detachment, forwarded direct.

7. NO EXPENSES INCURRED.

8. CONCLUDED - HANDED OVER.

In the P.M. of this date Mr. L. McCutcheon, Indian Agent at Fredericton called this Det., by phone and requested that members of this Det. pick up three children (Indians) at 77 Erin St., Saint John and convey them to the Union Station in the A.M. of 22-11-38 in time to catch the Halifax train and Mr. McCutcheon would be at the station and arrange for their transportation etc. to Shubenacadie, N.B.

This same date on instructions received, a patrol was made to Erin St., where James Paul, Father of Francis Paul, all years of age, Simon Paul, 6 years of age, and Beatrice Paul, 7 years of age reside. James Paul was requested to have the three children, Francis Simon and Beatrice ready to travel in the A.M. of the following date.

Transport Code No. 1637 used. Mileage on other cases.

In the Early A.M. of this date a phone call was received from Fredericton from Mr. McCutcheon advising that through unforeseen difficulties he would be unable to be at the station and meet the Halifax train and therefore would be grateful if members of this Det. would carry out the previous arrangements and see that the three Indian children were placed safely on the train in charge of the conductor.

Accordingly Francis Paul, Simon Paul, and Beatrice Paul were escorted to the UNION Station where tickets were purchased for them to Shubenacadie, N.B. A cash advance of $1.15 was made to Francis Paul and he was instructed to use this money to purchase himself and his brother and sister a lunch when he had to change trains at Moncton, N.B.

The Children were placed aboard the Halifax train and the tickets were handed to the conductor who agreed to look after the tickets and the children and see that they were safely transferred at Moncton, N.B. for Shubenacadie, N.B.

Since the expenses for tickets and cash advance were paid for out of the writer's pocket, receipt for three tickets ($3.60) attached. Total expense $4.75.

Transport Code No. 1637 used. Mileage on other cases.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from Mrs. Helen Nibby. It is rather difficult to understand the letter but I think she is referring to her children who are in the Shubenacadie residential school and who she apparently desires should be sent home for the Christmas holidays.

For many reasons which will no doubt suggest themselves to you the Department does not allow holidays at Christmas and I might say further that no valid reason has yet been given to us why holidays should be allowed at that period of the year.

There is no question that the children attending the Shubenacadie residential school receive every possible care and attention and in addition at Christmas time there are always special festivities which the children enjoy. For your information I enclose a copy of circular letter of March 30, 1937, governing holidays for children attending residential schools.

Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

Re: Indian Pupils to Shubenacadie School.

Enclosed please find six forms (Application for Admission) to Shubenacadie School, N.S., for six Indians of the Restigouche Reserve.

The matter has been discussed with Mr. J.E. Morris at his last visit at the agency; the parents have been interviewed, and Mr. Morris asked me to take the necessary steps to obtain their admission.

Those pupils are sent to Shubenacadie School for the following reasons:

1. Albert Condo's children.... There are 11 young children in the family, residing in a very small house. The father is T.B. treated at Quebec sanatorium, but comes home for three weeks or so from time to time. He is contagious for the rest of the family. An other child of that family, Aldric Condo, 16 years of age, has been declared T.B. lately and is at present at the Rimouski sanatorium since last week. In order to avoid more contagion of the whole family and more especially amongst the young children, I think the only way is to send the five other children to Shubenacadie School.

2. John Martin's child..... Mrs. Martin the mother has a very serious heart trouble and paralysed of one arm. Under doctor's recommendation, she can not do anything in the house. Mrs. Martin has explained her case to Mr. Morris himself at his last visit.

The four children who were attending Shubenacadie School last year will leave Monday next, September 1st, with the six new ones unless ordered to the contrary...... Rev. Father Brown has been notified accordingly.

E. Arsenault, Agent.
Charlottetown, P.E.I., August 26th, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch  
Department Of Mines & Resources  
OTTAWA.

Enclosed find five applications for admission to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

The three Bernard children have been at the St. Vincent's Orphanage Charlottetown since last fall, the father of these children died about two years ago, and the mother is unable to look after them properly, there seems to be no place for them except the Residential School.

Kathleen Paul has been at the Orphanage for the last six years, her board and care has been paid for by the Indian Affairs Branch, the Mother Superior felt it was time she was sent to the Indian School, the mother of this child has been in the Hospital for the Insane for the past two years, and we cannot find out where the father is at present.

Patrick Sylvan Paul son of Peter and Annie Paul cannot go to school at Rocky Point as there is no school there, therefore they would like to send him to the Indian school at Shubenacadie.

J. E. Daly  
Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am forwarding herewith an application for the admission of Donald Morrison, son of Charles Morrison, an Indian of the Middle River Reserve, Wyanza, N.S., to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School and you may note that it is not signed by the father.

Charles Morrison, the father of this child, is totally blind and is being led about by the boy while they roam from place to place. The mother died recently and the home now has only the father and son, the other children being placed with other Indian families. I am arranging to have Mr. Morrison transferred to Eskasoni and would be pleased to have the boy placed in the above named school where he could get the attention and education he is not now receiving. I brought the matter to Mr. Morrison's attention but he refused to sign the document as he does not wish to have the boy go to school on account of the assistance he gives him, leading him about. However, when the family are transferred to Eskasoni, the father can be attended to and will not require the services of his son in this respect, in fact it will be to the benefit of all concerned as, without the boy, the father cannot travel, without any necessary purpose, as much as he has been doing.

I would be pleased to have you authority to take the above referred to action as soon as possible.

F.B. McKinnon,
Indian Agent.

1. Further to above and memo re same from O.C., Halifax Sub-Division dated 19-7-48.

2. This matter was again taken up with Mr. Rice, the Indian Agent (reference to para. 1 of above-noted memo) and he stated that in view of the fact that he was also the Superintendent of the Indian School, that he could order the removal of the boy from the home of his father, if he thought that the conditions were unsuitable for the boy. Mr. Rice also agreed to accompany the patrol to Antrim in order to remove the boy.

3. 22-7-48. This date, Cst. Ecker and the writer, accompanied by Mr. Rice, patrolled to Antrim to the home of Charlie McLeod (Indian), where Russell McLeod was located. Charlie McLeod was very hostile towards Mr. Rice and his intentions of removing the boy to the Indian School, however, Mr. Rice ordered that the boy be taken, and he was placed in the police car, and transported to the Indian School at Shubenacadie, N.S.

4. After getting into the police car, and leaving the farm of his father, Russell McLeod expressed his gratefulness of the fact that the patrol had arrived to take him, as his father had been threatening to beat him that day, and hadn't been treating him very well. Upon arrival at the Indian School, his former home, he seemed very pleased and satisfied with the arrangements made for him, and was glad of his prospects of a decent life.

5. In view of the fact that the father of the boy was hostile about the boy's removal from his farm, it is possible that he might appear at the Indian School, and might influence the boy to leave. In considering this, Mr. Rice, the Indian Agent, stated that he did not want Charlie McLeod to put in an appearance at the Indian School at any time, and should he appear, he wanted the police notified and have him removed with a consideration of prosecutions.

6. As previously mentioned, the position of the boy at the school will be as an employee, under the supervision of Mr. White, the caretaker, who is most capable.

7. In view of the foregoing, this file is being closed at this detachment.

8. CONCLUDED HERE.

Cst. Ecker

September 22, 1947.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Attention: Bernard F. Neary,
Sup't of Indian Education.

Enclosed you will find two Applications for Admission forms for Barbara Atwin and Alvin Francis Atwin.

They are brother and sister who have lost their mother and father. They were making their home with their grandmother, Mrs. Mary Atwin. This woman appeared to be fond of the children but her sons, married men, stated that it was too much for her to look after the children as she was too old. I then decided to send them to Shubenacadie and had Dr. Wright fill in the forms on September 4th.

Mrs. Atwin wished to keep the children and suggested that she go to Kingsclear with them. I agreed to this but last Saturday, September 16th while I was away Mrs. Atwin brought the children to my house and left them. She was going to mine to pick potatoes, and she told me I could do with the children as I wished. I got in touch with Father Macleod and he informed me that he had room for these children; therefore, I am taking them to the school.

It will be noted that the signature of the father is missing as the father and mother are both dead and the grandmother who cared for them is in Maine and I do not know when she will return.

I trust that my action in this case meets with your approval and that these forms may be passed without a signature of parent or guardian.

Edward J. Whalen,
Sup't.,
N.B. West Indian Agency.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Enclosed you will find "Application For Admission" for two Indian children from the St. Mary's Band, Patricia Mary Sacobie and Raymond Gabriel Sacobie.

Michael Sacobie, father of these children died January 3, 1948 in Houlton, Maine, U.S.A. leaving a wife and five children. This family was living on the St. Mary's Reserve, but I moved them in the early summer to the Kingsclear Reserve. Mrs. Sacobie became ill and was sent to the St. Emile Tb Hospital. At that time, her sister, Mrs. Joseph Waterbury, who was married to a white man and lived at Dipper Harbour, Sunbury County, N.B. took the five children to care for them during the mother's illness. Mrs. Waterbury became poorly herself and had to give the children up. The oldest ones were taken to the Shubenacadie Residential School. The younger ones have been placed in another home at the Kingsclear Reserve.

No examination was made of these children before taking them to the school, as they were some distance from Fredericton, N.B. I got in touch with Dr. Wright, however, and he assured me that both children were healthy and fit to be taken to the school.

These children were placed in the Shubenacadie Residential School on November 8, 1948.

I trust this action meets with your approval.

Dear Sir:

Reference your letter dated December 17th, please be advised that John and Edward Condo, also Hullman Isaac, were sent to Shubenacadie Residential School on Thursday morning, December 23rd. I had wired Rev. J.P. Mackey and asked him if it would be acceptable to him to have them sent on that day and he advised me immediately to send them.

Hullman Isaac attended Shubenacadie last year and as stated in your letter to me dated Nov. 30th, that it applied to this boy, I sent him with the other two. I took it upon myself to let these boys travel alone after having obtained their tickets, given them enough money to buy sandwiches etc., and advised them that it was for their benefit that all this was being done. I expect word within the next day or two from Rt. Rev. J.P. Mackey, Principal, telling me of their arrival.

I have four or five others whom I would like to send but as I cannot get any cooperation from the parents I would ask your kind advice in the matter, there are at least three in the family of Mrs. Albert Condo, who should be going to school but are not. I spoke to the mother about them and she told me she would send them to the Day School on the Reserve, this she has not done. This woman is in receipt of a war pension which gives her $169.00 per month, made up as follows, $75.00 for herself, $18.00 for the first child, $15.00 for the second, and $14.00 for the third and subsequent children.

Seeing that this woman won't cooperate with me, is it not possible to have them stop payment of this pension, (Child's share) for those of school age who are not attending, in this way she will be brought to realize that it is costing her a lot of money and will then see to it that they either go to Shubenacadie or attend the Day School on the Reserve. I have advised the Department that it would be better to have this pension administered through this office for various other reasons.
I also have Elizabeth Vienre and Harry Isaac whose parents will not do anything about sending them to school, can these children be sent to school even though the parents will not cooperate? I realize that it is not much use trying to force them to go as it would only mean that they would cause us more trouble and expense than it would be worth; they would probably run away or do something else equally as foolish.

The situation is at present that these children are on the road all hours of the night, and if something is not done they will eventually all be in trouble, particularly the girls.

Your advice and recommendations would be greatly appreciated. At the beginning of the new term I am going to refuse relief completely to those families who have children of school age who are not attending, unless they have a very good reason. Awaiting your reply and recommendations.

If Mrs. Condo does not send her children regularly to day school on the Reserve, you should interview her again within the next two weeks, and endeavour to secure permission to send the children to the Shubenacadie School. If she refuses, you should write us and we will issue further instructions to you.

With regards to the final paragraph of your letter, I understand from the Welfare Section that we cannot justify refusing relief to an indigent Indian family in order to enforce school attendance. You can, of course, cancel Family Allowance where a child of school age does not attend regularly when school facilities are available.

Bernard F. Neary,
PP/ST

Principal,

Dear Msgr. Mackey:

With reference to your letter of the 4th instant, we are now advised by the Superintendent of the Restigouche Agency that three boys were sent to your school about the end of December, and I trust they reached there safely.

There is a possibility that we can secure additional children at Restigouche, and I am writing to the Superintendent again today.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Can.

Reference your letter dated January 21st., with regard to school children.

The three boys sent to Shubenacadie Residential School arrived safely and are apparently getting along alright; in a letter received from Rt.Rev. J.P.Mackey, he tells me that it is very difficult to try and handle boys of 12 and 14 years of age who have not attended any school regularly, as it means that they have to be placed in classes where the children are much younger etc.

With regard to Mrs.Condo, all her children of school age with the exception of one girl who will be 15 years of age next June, I have not interviewed this woman lately, as I am waiting for the report of Mr.Giroux, of the Canadian Pension Commission, Quebec, who visited this Agency about two weeks ago, he visited the school and obtained what information he required from the Mother Superior, and also the Parish Priest, Rev.Father Lucien, they both advised him that from their point of view, her pension was poorly administered and recommended that it be administered by the Department and this Office.

At present the general attendance at school is good, and we are not having too much difficulty in this regard.

As soon as I hear further xxx in connection with administration of xxx Mrs.Condo's pension, you will be notified.

Memo to Indian Affairs Branch.

Re attached applications for entry to the Ind. Res. School.

Fabian 7, Mary Teresa, and Levi Joseph 14, are children of John Joe of Eskasoni. They are part of a family of seven and the family are in straitened circumstances.

The father is a steady worker, not too bright. The mother has spent several periods in the N.S. asylum and is not at all a fit person to handle children in the adolescence stage.

These children are undernourished and somewhat neglected. Skin diseases spread through the family from lack of care. Like a number of Indian parents these people think a boy or girl after ten or twelve should have the dealing of events as they pertain to them. I think this oldest boy should have some control and supervision, as we have caught him several times in truancy and misbehaviour. These incidents were all small but indicative of the possibilities if he is not checked.

F.B. McKimmy
Supt. Indian Agency.

I am forwarding application for admission forms for four Indian children to the Shubenacadie Residential School.

Your letter file 440-148(W2), dated June 25, 1949 is acknowledged.

Both parents of the boy Stephen Simon Peters are dead. This child was six years old on the 27th of June of this year. Arrangements are being made for his admission to the Shubenacadie School at the earliest opportunity.

Arthur Francis was three years old on the 18th of March, 1949. His father is crippled and his mother has recently been discharged from hospital where she had undergone prolonged treatment for advanced tuberculosis. There are four other children in the family, and their present house is inadequate. Their financial circumstances are such that the parents are unable to contribute to the support of this boy, and no other family here is willing to accept him.

Two of the older children will be attending the Shubenacadie School this fall. I would recommend that the child Arthur remain in the orphanage until that time, when he can return to the care of his mother. Were he to return now, the added burden might easily result in the mother suffering a relapse, when the full responsibility for this large family would devolve on the Branch.

The two Condo Children are in need of care and attention, in that their father is now in prison in Maine awaiting trial, and the Mother is an individual of low mentality, she will be left with three others and is expecting another in the near future, the two which I want to send to Shubenacadie, are, Raymond and Joseph Hunts, Raymond was nine in January last and Joseph Hunts, will be seven in December, two of the older boys of this family are now in the school having gone there last December.

Dear Sir,

I am returning the requested forms in connection with Stephen Peters.

We are never eager to keep children for a lengthy period but this is one case where I think a change would be undesirable. Stephen finds it very difficult to make adjustments to new places and different people. His Mother's very sudden death evidently was a severe shock to him and now that he seems so happy and contented with his little playmates after so many months of maladjustment it seems a shame to transplant him again. To place him in a permanent home it would be worth the effort but simply to go to another Boarding school it doesn't seem worth while.

Yours respectfully,

Enclosed herein please find application for admission of Herby Martin, born 13-1-1943 and Ralph Martin, born 4-6-1944, into the Shubenacadie Residential School.

These two boys are the children of Albert P. Martin, Indian of Maria Reserve, actually residing at Restigouche. Mr. and Mrs. Martin, were involved in a car accident last summer, Mrs. Martin was seriously injured, suffering with a compound thigh fracture, will be in the hospital for quite sometime yet. As Mr. Martin cannot leave his five children to go outside and earn a living and procure the necessaries for his family, I would appreciate if consideration was given to this matter.

By having these two children off his hands Mr. Martin could have the other three cared for and thus be able to get away from his home. It would also permit Mrs. Martin, on her discharge from the hospital, to get along better by having only the three children to look after until she fully recovers.

This office communicated with Rt. Rev. J.P. MacKey, Principal, Shubenacadie Res. School and children will be admitted upon Department's approval.

(C.R. Nadeau) Supt.

Enclosed you will find an "Application for Admission" for an Indian girl, Patricia Mary Sacobie, of the Saint Mary's Indian Reserve to be placed in the Shubenacadie Residential School.

This girl was in the Shubenacadie Residential School in 1948, while her mother was a patient in the TB Hospital (St. Basile, N.B.) On the mother's arrival home, she wished the children with her and decided to keep them home and send them to school. She died, however, on September 4, 1949, and her brother, Edward, took the family to live with him.

He went to Maine to pick potatoes shortly after that and took the children with him. Therefore, they missed school the greater part of September and October. This man did a fairly good job with the children while he had a housekeeper (wife dead) but when she went away, it was not fit for a girl of Patricia's age, as Paul has a family of boys and no girls.

This girl was taken to the Shubenacadie Residential School on March 1, 1950, by Miss Alexa Howard, field nurse.

I trust my action in this case meets with your approval.

Edward J. Whalen,
Sup't.,

We are in receipt of your letter of
the 3rd instant with reference to conditions on the above
reserve.

Careful consideration has been given to
the contents of your letter but as you know no provision
was made in the current year's appropriation for the erection
of a new school on this reserve, therefore, consideration can
not be given to your suggestion that you be authorized to
proceed with the erection of a new building.

On checking the March Quarterly Return
of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School it is found
that there are twenty children from the Eskasoni Reserve
and twenty-eight children from the Sydney Reserve attending
that school. There must be many children who could attend
a day school at either Eskasoni or Sydney.

Please review the needs of all children
both from Eskasoni and Sydney Reserves who are attending the
Shubenacadie School and if their parents are in a position
to support them they should attend either of these day schools
just mentioned.

You should let me know not later than
August 1, 1950, the names of those children from both Sydney
and Eskasoni who will not return to Shubenacadie School for
the academic year 1950-51.
The vacancies at Shubenacadie Residential School as a result of the number of children just mentioned not returning can be filled by placing the children from Whyccocomagh in the residential school for the coming academic year.

When preparing your estimates for the fiscal year 1951-52, you may include an amount for the erection of a day school on the Wh cocomagh Reserve and we will give this application careful consideration when a final decision is made regarding the 1951-52 appropriation. When making this request, you should state definitely the number of children who would attend day school on the Whyccocomagh Reserve if erected and their ages. You should also let us know if the families who are at present living on this reserve are likely to remain there for the next few years. Otherwise, it will not be possible to erect a new day school on that reserve.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Citizenship and Immigration,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Herewith are three applications for admission to the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie:

(1) Shirley Marie Lewis, the daughter of Matthew and Martha Lewis, band No. 171. The father deserted the family approximately two years ago and they are on total relief. Four other children of this family attend the school regularly and are being readmitted this year.

(2) George Francis. This boy is the son of Frank Francis, Band No. 74, Eskasoni Band. He is of low IQ and the father does not appear to have too much control. This child is a definite liability in our day school. I believe that a few years in the Residential School, where discipline is maintained at all times, might do this boy some good.

(3) Eugene Daniel Paul. This boy is the son of John N. Paul, Band No. 220. He has all the ear marks of a prospective juvenile delinquent. His father, who works away from home considerably, seems unable to exact any discipline from him. He is a definite liability in the day school. I believe that a few years in the Residential School under discipline at all times might work to advantage in his case. However, I will not be surprised if he will end up in a Reformatory. I believe most of his trouble is a lack of discipline on the part of his parents.

(Continued)
I trust approval will be granted to have these children admitted.

After conferring with Monsignor Mackey and learning that sufficient room was available I presumed permission to place in the school the following three children whose applications arrived too late to allow for authorization to be received before opening date:

(1) Emma Johnson, daughter of Ben N. Johnson, and
(2) Diana and Lena Toney, children of Benjamin Toney, of Whycocomagh.

Proper application forms will be completed immediately. The children will be examined medically by Dr. Hayey and the forms will be forwarded by Monsignor Mackey.

I trust this action meets with your approval.

F. B. McKinnon,
Regional Supervisor,
Indian Agencies.

On September 17, 1951, I was asked to go to St. Peter's, Nova Scotia to sit in on a trial of two Indian children, charged with the theft of a few cents plus a revolver from a white neighbor. The children were Paul and Bruno Isaac, aged 13 and 11, respectively; issue of John Issac of the Chapel Island band.

The parents of these children are shiftless and intemperate. There is considerable record of infractions, such as these, against almost all members of this family due, I believe, chiefly to the neglect of the parents.

Rather than have them committed to St. Patrick's Home, I asked the Magistrate to release them in my custody and admitted them to the Shubenacadie Residential School on the 20th day of September, 1951.

I trust this action meets with your approval. Applications will go forward as soon as Monsignor Mackey arranges to have them medically examined.

Signed F. B. McKinnon,
Regional Supervisor,
Indian Agencies.

I have forwarded to Monsignor J. P. Mackey, Principal of the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, N.S., application forms covering the admission of Bruno and Paul Isaac, Indian youths of Barra Head Reserve, Eskasoni Agency.

These boys were being tried for a minor theft and at my request the Magistrate released them to my custody. Knowing the family background, it was apparent that the only solution was their admission to the Indian Residential School. This move was opposed violently by the parents and it was necessary to forcibly remove the children, which was done at the request of the Magistrate, who would have undoubtedly placed them in a Reformatory as it was their second offense.

The forms are being forwarded directly from the School without the signatures of their parents and I trust they will be accepted in this manner.

J. B. McKinnon,
Regional Supervisor,
Indian Agencies.

Re: Children of Levi Pictou, Springhill Junction, Cumberland Co., N. S.

Attached herewith are applications for Wanda May, Murray Allen and Hubert Lorman children of the above Indian man, dated July 22, 1952.

Mr. Pictou had the misfortune of losing his wife a few months ago and was unable to care for the children and he and his older son left for Maine, U. S. A. and as there was no one to care for these children I was forced to place them in the Residential School, Shubenacadie, N. S. on July 22, 1952.

As this was a case of an emergency I feel that you will approve of the action I took in this case, and it is recommended that approval from July 22nd, to the Residential School be granted for these children.

H. C. Rice, Superintendent,
Shubenacadie Indian Agency,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration.

Herewith are three applications for admission into the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School for children of Eskasoni Indian Reserve.

(1) Charlène E. Francis, daughter of Frank and Rosie Francis, band # 74. The parents have requested the admission of this child because of the unsatisfactory physical condition of Mrs. Francis. There are five children in the family, an older brother admitted to the Residential School last September.

(2) Elmer Lewis. This youth is only five years of age but his parents are separated and are living somewhere in the New England States, having abandoned their large family. Five older brothers and sisters are already in the Residential School which will lessen to a degree the responsibility on the School staff for his care. Living with relatives who do not want him is an unsatisfactory atmosphere in which to bring up this child and I feel he will be much better physically and temperamentally re-united with his older brothers and sisters.

(3) Albert Julian. This boy's father is dead and his mother remarried John T. Johnson, Band # 157. He is a bright, strong-willed, mischievous youngster, not receiving adequate care and supervision from his step-father. I recommend his admission to the Residential School.

Attention Education Division,

May authority be granted to send three children to Shubenacadie Residential School. Rt. Rev. J.P. MacKey reports that he would accept them at any time.

The children are from the Eel River Reserve, in New-Brunswick, Ruby JULIAN born July 21, 1939, Lois Geneiveve JULIAN, born February 20, 1941 and Albert JULIAN, born December 21, 1944. The father and mother have more or less deserted their children, having left them over a year ago all by themselves with three others between the ages of two, five and 16 years old.

So far these children have been taken care by another Indian of the Eel River Reserve but as she now finds it too much work, I would recommend that the three mentioned above be sent to Shubenacadie Residential School.

If the Department concur with my recommendation, may the children be sent immediately and forms duly filled will follow, in this case it will also be impossible to obtain the consent of the parents.

May I be advised as soon as possible.

Herewith are applications for admission to the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie for two Indian Boys of Eskasoni Agency:

NOVA SCOTIA TECHNICAL COLLEGE
HALIFAX, NOVA SCOTIA

March 8, 1941

Mr. Phillip Phalen
Superintendent of Training
Department of Mines & Resources
Indian Affairs Branch
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

I have called several times during the past year at the Indian School at Shubenacadie because I have been interested in the progress Sister Paul has made in teaching pottery to the students. Father Mackey and I have discussed the economic possibilities of this type of work and I think he has now agreed that much could be done with the Indian children if he had the facilities. Present drains on finances are severe and I can easily understand restricted budgets. However, with comparatively small expenditures articles in clay sold on the main highway like the one running through Shubenacadie would soon produce results. Furthermore this is the only place in the province where we could get characteristic Indian designs from the Indians themselves and Sister Paul is trying to develop these.

Father Mackey will discuss the possibility of a kiln with Mr. Shaw of L. E. Shaw Company, and I think co-operation from that source is assured. The Provincial Department of Industry and Public Information through its minister is interested in developing this work throughout the province. Publicity and perhaps some subsidy can be secured for impoverished localities, but other than for the publicity it may not be possible to secure aid for the Indian School.

I am writing you this letter so you will be informed about the possibilities in Shubenacadie and the attempt we would like to see made to aid the Indian children in acquiring a skill based on a natural resource plentiful in the province. My impression is that skill in pottery making would be a valuable addition with economic possibilities to the commercially known one which the Indians possess, the making of baskets. Our hope is that in the near future we shall be able to command some of the local market for clay products which is at the present time being satisfied from outside our provincial limits.

Anything you can do to help us in this matter through
Mr. P. P...........(2)

providing the Indian School with the necessary equipment which is not expensive would be much appreciated.

I may have occasion to be in Ottawa within a short time and if I do I shall try to make an appointment to see you.

Yours very truly,

E. K. Ford.
Inspector, Local Technical Schools & Mechanic Science Departments.

EKF:C
Ottawa,
March 13, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I am extremely interested in the contents of your letter of the 8th instant and this Branch is quite willing to give Father Mackey and Sister Paul as much assistance as our finances will permit.

I note that the necessary equipment will not be expensive and I am writing to Father Mackey today to ascertain the exact expenditure involved.

We appreciate the interest that you are taking in this project and whenever you are in Ottawa I would be glad to have you call on me.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

It is too bad so much delay has occurred in getting to Father Mackey of the Shubenacadie Indian School the specifications and costs of a ceramic kiln and further too bad I missed you when you were here. The past few days I have had in the office and some definite information is now available.

We have the drawings, descriptions, and cost estimates of a kiln that can be built for $200. The price given me was $150 but I arbitrarily added $50. Single firings can be completed at about $2.00. From the specifications we have I am satisfied that the work can be done with local labour.

When the matter was first discussed I believed we could construct a small kiln suitable for school or small production purposes at a cost of $200 or $250 which would burn wood or coal. Subsequent careful investigation showed that the cost of underground flues, smoke stack, ironing for bracing and other factors would run the cost to several hundred dollars. Furthermore the successful use of such kilns, I learned, requires much skill and even experienced men have considerable losses on any new kiln. For such reasons the small outside wood-fired kiln was given up even though it at first looked promising in view of our estimated future needs in various localities in the province.

The specifications we have provide for an electrically heated kiln, inside measurements, 18 inches approximately by two feet; lined with light refractory (heat resistant) brick; outside shell, steel plate, standing on ordinary hollow building tile for ventilation beneath; no stacks or flues necessary; and operated off either 110 or 220 volt circuit with no transformer necessary. Such a kiln can be set up in a building anywhere, is very easy to operate because the element of judgment as to heating is largely eliminated. The switches are thrown in and the kiln brought to heat checked by cones. The light refractory brick use a .06 cone, I judge about 1800°F. The price on this job should not exceed $200 including the electric heating coils. One has been in use in New Brunswick for some time and the owner maintains he

can set them up for $100. I am a little skeptical of this estimate. Single firing prices are given at $1.50 where electricity costs 2½ cents per k.w.h. I think it is more in Shubenacadie so I allowed $2.00 which is probably below the operating costs of either wood or oil due to economy of burning.

As you know the Technical Education Branch has taken the first step in our appropriate field - that of training workers. The training project has grown from a class of 15 at Mahone Bay in 1937 to three classes enrolling 50 at Antigonish this summer and we had to turn one class away. In reply to your letter concerning the kiln:- After receiving the copy of your letter to Mr. Ford, we began trying to get details of construction and materials needed.

Mr. Ford, and we, ourselves, were of the opinion that a kiln could be built suitable for our purposes, which could be fired by wood or coal. Mr. Shaw, President and Owner of the N.S. Clay Works promised to give us all the help he could. We interviewed Mr. Shaw about it at least on two occasions, and we did not seem to be getting anywhere. Finally, Mr. Ford, knowing that this work was done in St. John and near St. John, decided that in order to get a real line on things, the best thing to do was to go to St. John. He went in his car, and took Mr. McLeod, our carpenter-engineer with him. Our expenses in the trip was the hotel bill for Mr. McLeod.

As a result of this trip Mr. McLeod obtained information as to where the high test brick could be obtained, and the construction of the kiln itself. But instead of being fired by coal or wood, the heating would be done by electricity. Mr. McLeod has since constructed a kiln, so Mr. Ford says, much better than any they saw on the trip to St. John.

As for high test brick and asbestos slabs, a firm, Prescott & Company, of Montreal, was recommended. We made up the specifications and asked them to supply the material. First they wanted to know if they could send the material C.O.D. Our reply was that the Department of Indian Affairs would pay for it, or if they were not satisfied with that, let us know the amount due and we would send the money before they made the shipment. Finally when they did ship it they wanted to know if they could send a sight draft to the Department. We sent them a check immediately.
immediately for One Hundred and Twenty-six Dollars and Eighty-eight cents.

We needed steel plate for the outside, and of course, we could not buy it new, so we hunted around and located an old tender of an engine and got our plates there. We also bought second hand fire brick. There was difficulty getting new fire brick, and the cost had gone up considerably.

Well, we had enough material to start the construction of the kiln. So ahead Mr. Macleod went. Next we were held up for the electrical wire and terminals. Mr. Ford, along with Professor Nicol, electrical engineer, spent a good part of last Friday, January 2nd, here, looking over the kiln, and working out the details for the heating. Dear Mr. Hoey:

We are very glad that you are pleased with the samples of pottery, which Mr. Rice so kindly brought to Ottawa.

The start was made about three years ago, when the Provincial Department of Education, established a summer school, in order to develop teachers for pottery. The Sisters of Charity were invited to send representatives to this summer school, and Sister Paul of the Cross, of the staff here, was one of the chosen ones.

Under the impetus given by Mr. Ford, of the N.S. Technical College, we began some work, and also began exploratory work about a kiln. At that time we thought that a kiln could be built in which coal and wood would be used as fuel. We spent a lot of time on it, but got nowhere. By this time, Sister Paul of the Cross had completed two courses, at summer school. In the meantime, we had collected a number of pieces of pottery, and still, had no way of firing or baking them. Mr. Ford then wrote to the Department of Indian Affairs, and we obtained the sum of Two Hundred Dollars towards the building of a kiln. All thought of wood or coal as fuel was abandoned, and it was decided to go ahead with an electric kiln. They have electric kilns in New Brunswick, so Mr. McLeod, our carpenter-engineer, was sent there to look them over. With further assistance from the N.S. Technical College, we got the blue prints, and Mr. McLeod went ahead, and built the kiln, which, from all accounts, was quite an improvement on what he had seen in New Brunswick. We were held up for a long time before we succeeded in getting any heating wire. Finally, we did get it - the first of this year. We were given details by an electrical engineer from the Technical College, and to an amateur, it looked quite complicated. However, anyone who knew anything about electricity was contacted, even to passengers in the smoking compartment on trains, concerning volts, kilowatts, amps, load, and many other things. Finally, we interested a man by the name of Smith, from Stewiacke, the next village, and while holding no degrees from any college, has a very definite talent for things electrical.
We rigged the kiln according to the specifications of the electrical engineer, and it was not satisfactory, and so Smith told us what he would do. We contacted the electrical engineer, and he gave us all sorts of warnings, what would happen, if we used heavy wiring, and increased the amperage. It was no good as it was, and we spent plenty of money on it, so we spent another fifty dollars, for wire, fuse boxes, etc., and decided that soon we would know whether we had something or nothing. We have had ten or eleven firings, and everything has gone very satisfactorily. Now they want us to do bookings for other sections.

We have had a visit from representatives of the N.S. Dept. of Industry, and the supervisor for handicraft seemed more than surprised to learn that the clay for our work is found on the side of a ditch about a hundred yards from the school.

Our problem now is to find a glaze that will take well on both the red and white clay. Miss Black, the supervisor of handicrafts for the province is going to take a ten pound sample to a Danish family in New Brunswick, who have been making pottery for generations, and also making their own glazes. The peculiar thing about it is that they import their clay from Musquodoboit, in Nova Scotia.

When Mr. Doucet was here, we were hoping that we might obtain a potters wheel. The one we have was put together by Mr. McLeod, from a defunct potato peeler, cover from the top of a stove, part of a sewing machine, and the motor from a discarded household washing machine. Of course it has only the one speed, and does not run exactly true. In our last requisition for school supplies, we asked for one, and while most of the supplies arrived, we have not heard anything about the potters wheel.

It is our intention to produce for sale, and if the time ever comes again, to cater to the tourist trade. The kiln is 21" wide, 24" deep, and 27" high, rather larger than we expected to build. We have had as many as sixty-two pieces fired at one time, and as low as fifty-two, depending of course, on the size.

At the present time, we have four classes, 1 for boys, and three for girls, and some are exceptionally good at it. By the time the younger ones are old enough to be discharged, they should be quite proficient in it. It is our intention to concentrate as much as possible on Indian designs. We hope to get some valuable information along that line from the Fort Anne Museum at Annapolis Royal. On the other hand, Mr. Ford told us the other day that if we would make for him one hundred bean crocks, he would sell them between here and Halifax.
We have no separate meter for the kiln, but since no other power is used when it is going, and also that our power charges have been quite uniform for years, we figure that a firing up to 1800 degrees, costs between three and four dollars. We have been offered all the clay we want from a former brick yard plant, and from Mr. Lawlor, a former Indian Agent. We feel quite sure that we can get a first class fire clay that will bake out white. Clay from anywhere near here is quite satisfactory.

At the present time, we have already fired and ready for glazing about three hundred pieces. We shall go ahead and try different clays, and in that way, have as much variety as possible. As soon as we are ready, Lawlor's store has offered to make a window display for us. We expect to have about a hundred pieces on display there by the end of this week.

We hope to purchase a stamp, about the size of a five cent piece, and have an Indian head in the center, and M I C H A C around the edge, and use that to indicate the Indian origin.

They have pottery as one of the subjects at Mt. St. Bernard, affiliated with St. Francis Xavier University at Antigonish. There they have an oil burner kiln, but from what we have heard, it is not too satisfactory, and requires a lot of attention.

We have used to a limited extent some of the diagrams on the cards you sent. If you think it would be worth while, we would be glad to send to the Department a number of pieces for sale, say from fifty to seventy-five.

We would be grateful if Miss Moodie would send us samples of glaze, especially red color.

Hope we have not overtaxed your patience with this lengthy epistle.

Yours very truly,

Dear Father Mackey:

On my return from duty on reserves, Mr. Hoey handed me your letter of May 17 regarding your pottery project at Shubenacadie, and he suggest that I should write you in this connection.

Your letter is most interesting, and I can well imagine some of your difficulties. It is wonderful, however, to have such good clay available, and to have found out already how to handle a kiln. Have you considered producing more primitive unglazed articles? There is ready sale for such goods, although they have to be very carefully packed, and they are used for things not required to hold liquids. They would not be suitable for pitchers, for instance, but I have seen candle holders, match holders, ash trays, etc., simply baked, and sold in the natural color—I believe potters call these baked, unglazed articles, "biscuits".

As for design—the less ornamentation there is, the better the article seems to sell, except that at present there is a vogue for "slip-painting" before baking. The potter makes a thin paste of clay, which is colored by artificial means if necessary, and "slip-paints" a simple design which may be just irregular lines or daubs. If the article is light in color, they use dark-colored clay. If it is dark in color, they use light-colored clay, and the variations are endless. The simpler the design the better.

Kjeld and Erica Deichman, of Moss Glen, N.B., are about the best potters in Canada. Besides having wonderful artistic sense, they are very practical—and these may be the people Miss Black, the N.S. Supervisor, referred to. If you could get Mr. and Mrs. Deichman to spend a week or two at your school, I believe any expenditure involved would be well worth while. They are not mercenary, and are sincerely interested in promoting the production of good pottery. Mr. Deichman makes their own potter's wheels—he used an old car axle, sewing machine treadle, etc. (something as you did), but he is sufficiently experienced to
to have been able to get his wheels to run true, and he governs the speed by foot-pedal. He makes the larger articles—vases, jars, bowls, etc., on the wheel, and his wife is particularly skilled in modelling by hand-method, charming little animal figures—colts, lambs (and sometimes humans). She uses an old gramophone to provide her with a wheel. These two have experimented and found wonderful glazes, and here again, I can recommend no better source of information than Mr. Deichman.

If you could produce even one or two small articles in quantity, I would love to include them in our catalogue and price-list of handicraft merchandise—but our orders come to us requiring quantities of from one to 12 gross of a line. The only times I can sell small lots of goods are when we put on exhibitions, and these are out for the duration. We could certainly use ash trays, small bowls to hold matches, candle holders, etc., in the unglazed "biscuit"—but we would need to have samples of two or three very plain, simple designs of each, and then decide on one of each, and definitely try to produce in quantity. It would be a wonderful thing to have a pottery centre in the village, where your graduates could earn their living after leaving school. Certainly there is great opportunity for the sale of pottery, but it will require great care in figuring the prices per dozen articles to be paid to the workers, and the prices to be charged the wholesalers. With our basketry sales we have our list price—and the selling agency is given a discount of 30 per cent to cover costs of selling and collecting accounts. In addition, we add from 5 to 20 per cent to cover transportation costs from reserves, packing, cartons, etc.,—so the wholesale price has to be considerably higher than the price paid to the workers.

I have always hoped to get back to Shubenacadie since my one short visit there when the school was barely completed. Now that I know of this pottery achievement I am twice as anxious! I do hope you will find it possible to engage the Deichmans for at least a short period, and that they will be able to iron out some of the difficulties you have encountered.

Yours sincerely,

These nimble fingers plucking eagerly at an age-old art, followed in the days when their forefathers were rounding the uncivilized Canadian wilks, children at the Indians Residential School at Shubenacadie are turning out objects of art that would grace any modern home.

"Making mud pots," an enjoy-able pastime. The children do the shaping over a heavy chair. Dig it up and bring it to the firing oven. This is accomplished by the use of firewood, wood and lime. The electric kiln is used to shape the clay, removes the moisture and fires the pieces. The electric kiln is simply one of the many improvements made in the school.

Memorandum: CHIEF PURCHASING AGENT

During the past few years the pupils in the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School have been given instruction in pottery making. There is a deposit of unusually fine clay on the school property, and the school has installed an electric kiln for firing the articles produced. Through local sales of these articles the Sister in charge of the pottery group informed Inspector Arnell that they have sufficient funds to purchase an electric potter's wheel, but in order to secure the one they desire they have been informed by the Denver Fire Clay Company that "a priority of AA-3 or better" is required. Apparently the Sister did not know how to go about securing any priority and when Inspector Arnell visited Shubenacadie she requested our assistance.

I enclose the letter from the Denver Fire Clay Company, together with cuttings from some catalogue which Sister Paul of the Cross gave to Inspector Arnell. The wheel which they decided upon is the Amaco Electric Potter's Wheel No.2 -- $198.00 plus tax which I believe brings the cost to approximately $250.00. This does not take into consideration the fact that payment should be made in American funds.

I will appreciate it very much if you could arrange to secure the wheel in question -- to be shipped to:

The Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.,
Canada.

The account could be paid through this office and collected from the school.

I feel that the work done under the direction of Sister Paul of the Cross is very creditable and I am anxious to do everything possible to assist her in promoting this work. I might mention that I communicated with the Sister and suggested a foot power wheel which could be secured at a lower cost. She has replied, however, that they prefer the electric wheel as the foot power wheels are too high to be used by smaller children.

Sister Paul of the Cross has requested that the letter from The Denver Fire Clay Company and the catalogue cuttings attached should be returned to her.

R.A. Hoey,
Acting Director
Dear Father Brown:

When Inspector Arneil visited Shubenacadie he was very much impressed by the progress which had been made in the production of pottery under the direction of Reverend Sister Paul of the Cross. At that time the Reverend Sister gave to Inspector Arneil some correspondence from The Denver Fire Clay Company, together with a catalogue cutting showing the type of electric wheel which the Sister had been trying to secure. It was understood that if at all possible we were to secure a Government priority and place an order for an Amaco Electric Potter's Wheel, Number 2, Floor Model, (list price $198.00).

We have been able to have this order placed and the total estimated cost, which includes exchange on the purchase of American funds, war tax, excise, etc., is $317.00.

We have been advised by the Chief Purchasing Agent that the wheel will probably be shipped to the Port of Entry nearest Shubenacadie (possibly Truro), and that it will be necessary for someone to go from Shubenacadie in order to clear the wheel through the Customs. The wheel will be released from the Customs after you have paid the account for duty and excise, which will amount to approximately $60.00.

As the order has been placed through the Department of Mines and Resources, payment for the wheel itself must be made by cheque from this department. As we are nearing the end of the fiscal year our funds for the purchase of equipment have been exhausted, and it is necessary, therefore, to ask you to mail to me your cheque for $250.00, payable to Receiver General of Canada, and including on the face of the cheque the identifying word "Shubenacadie". It is possible that after the account is paid in American funds there will be some small balance which of course will be returned to you.

I have no doubt that you are conversant with the arrangements between Inspector Arneil and Reverend Sister Paul of the Cross, and I may say we are pleased to have been able to be of assistance in this matter.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF INDIAN EDUCATION

Re: Schubenacadie Indian Residential School.

The Schubenacadie Residential School has an enrolment of 158 children. The junior division have 68 children in the classroom; the intermediate 35 and the senior 55. It will be necessary to operate a fourth classroom. There is space available. A room originally intended for a classroom is being used as storage and for the pottery. This room which is identical to one of the classrooms would be, after a general clean-up, very suitable. I would suggest that the principal submit estimates for the preparation of this room.

There is no workshop and no space available for one. It will be necessary to build a separate building that would serve as a workshop, (general shop and pottery) and also provide storage space. The principal should obtain estimates for a building that would supply his needs.

Respectfully submitted,

A. J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Vocational Education.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The room reported on by Mr. Doucet is not exactly a store room. It is the room opposite Grade 1, and has been used as a workshop and also a place for making pottery.

To make a classroom would require plastering around most of the windows, sanding of the floor, and two coats of paint on walls and ceiling. These with other little things would cost from $150.00 to $200.00. In addition there would be black-board 40-50 feet and twenty movable desks—10 small and 10 medium.

Since the room with the kiln is next to the garage, we could have the garage as the shop for the pottery class. The garage for the car (if it comes) could be attached to the workshop and manual training.

We do not know what Mr. Doucet has in mind but we think a building forty by thirty, outside measurement, giving two rooms twenty by thirty would do for manual training and workshop.

We at the school could do a good part of work. With the help of two carpenters, a building not furnished on the inside should not take longer than forty days to build. If the rooms were found to be too cold then something might be done to remedy the matter in another year.

We think we have taken everything into consideration and figure that at the most, renovation of classroom, garage and new building should not cost more than $4200.00.

Sincerely yours,

Dear Phil:

I am keeping to schedule and arrived at Shubenacadie last night. I find conditions here at the Residential School much better than on my last visit. You will note that we included some five thousand dollars in the Supplementary Estimates for the erection of a Manual Training shop at the Residential School. I think we will have to go ahead with the building in the near future even though the money may not be available for another month.

Would you please have Mr. Doucet send at once to Monseigneur Mackey, the drawing and the bill of materials for the Manual Training shop he intends to have built here. Most of the lumber can be supplied from the mill on the reserve at $40.00 per M. The Manual Training teacher can help with the erection and the sooner the plans get here, the sooner they can begin to get the building covered in.
