Ottawa, September 18th, 1929.

Reverend Sir,

I have been asked to make some suggestions to you in regard to the care of the health of the pupils who will soon come to your new school. I am sure that you realize the responsibility which you and the Department are assuming for the welfare of these children who will be away from their homes, and many of whom will come from homes where they have not had too good care and feeding.

In the first place you should resolutely refuse to receive any pupil who has tuberculosis in any form whether of the lungs or joints, or scrofula. The lot of such children may not now be happy, and you may think they will improve in the school, but tuberculosis in any form is contagious, and if you take them in you will have reason to regret it. They will give the disease to healthy children.

In the second place you will have to feed your pupils better than you would think necessary. The healthiest schools are those in which the feeding is best. I suppose you are getting cows. If you can give the children plenty of clean, whole milk you will be going far to keep them healthy. I do not believe in butter making at schools. The pupils ought to have the milk fat and butter too. A diet high in protein - fish, meat, beans, cheese, etc., seems best for Indians. Give them brown bread if possible. Your cows, of course, ought to be free from tuberculosis.

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.
Now, as for sick pupils, you must be always on the watch for contagious diseases. Every pupil must be vaccinated on entrance to school, unless there is clear evidence that he has been vaccinated within a year or two. Nearly all the Indian children in the Maritime Provinces have been recently vaccinated, and should have their certificates. You might find it wise to tell as many as you can to bring them with them. When any pupil has a fever he ought to be in bed, and you should watch for rashes, spotty sore throats, and other indications of contagious disease. Consult the doctor if you have any doubt about the matter. When any pupil develops tuberculosis he must be put away from the others. The Department will try to provide a place for him in Sanatorium, but in any case he cannot be left in the dormitory.

The Department has a travelling nurse in Nova Scotia, who will call on you from time to time. Nurse MacDonald is a good person, and will help you. A supply of drugs and dressings is now being ordered for you. I have selected them from an official list which you will receive. You may order more as you require them, but I must ask you to read the instructions on the list carefully, and observe how to go about it. You must also keep in mind that tonics and pills can never take the place of good food.

If I were asked to put down in a list the most important things which would keep your pupils in health, I should place them as follows:- kindness, good feeding, good ventilation, vigilance against contagious diseases and tuberculosis, and last of all and least, medicines.

You will have a doctor, who will I am sure, confirm all this and advise you in every way. You will receive circulars of instruction on which I have marked certain paragraphs to which your special attention is directed.

Yours truly,

M. B.

March 28th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

It has been decided to appoint you as medical attendant to the pupils of the Chibougamau Indian Residential School. Payment will be made for your services on the basis of the Department's schedule of fees. Under this schedule you will be allowed a fee of $2.00 for each pupil brought to you for examination prior to admission. The fee set down for a visit to the school is $5.00, but as you may be asked to see several pupils at each visit, a charge of $1.00 will be allowed for each additional pupil, with a maximum charge of $6.00. The schedule is thought to be quite clear in regard to operations and other procedures.

At schools of similar size elsewhere, the department does not expect the cost of medical attendance to exceed about $40.00 per month, including minor operations; and it is hoped that you may be able to keep the cost of your service within approximately this limit, but it is not intended that any child should be deprived of necessary medical attention, and it is hoped that this school, which is the first of its kind in the Maritime provinces, may have a high standard of health.

It is desired that you will make a semi-annual examination of all pupils during the months of September and March, so that you may be able to detect any tendency toward tuberculosis or other cause of

[Signature]

D.F. Collins, M.D.
Chibougamau, N.B.
failure in health. For each such examination the Department is prepared to pay a special fee of $50.00, and for this fee expects a complete examination and adequate report.

You will probably find a number of pupils who require the correction of minor defects such as removal of tonsils and dental attention. The Department, in such cases, wishes to have a report made by the Doctor and Principal, so that special instructions may be given.

It has been suggested that a special examination of all pupils for the presence of tuberculosis should be made by the Provincial Clinic. No definite arrangements have been made for this, and you will be informed of any action decided upon.

The Principal of the school is the guardian of the pupils, and is responsible to the Department for their welfare. You should consult his views in the same way as you do those of parents in your private practice.

I shall be pleased to receive your acceptance of this appointment, and the Department will endeavour to explain any matters which have not been made clear.

Yours very truly,
Indian Residential School.

April 16th, 1930.

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that we had a case of acute appendicitis in the person of Margaret Cremo. The advice of the doctor was to send her to Halifax for an operation. Sister Superior went with the child. Two hours after the arrival of the train she was operated on. I got in touch with the Mother and had her consent.

Yours very truly,

Mr. A.F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
Halifax, N. S., April 28, 1930.

Dr. D. F. McInnis,
Physician to Indian School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

Dear Dr. McInnis:

Attached you will find my report on examination of the school children for tuberculosis. For your convenience I am sending a copy of the examination cards to the school, to be placed on file there. I am also sending a copy of this report to be left at the school for future reference and a copy for the Dept. of Indian Affairs.

I shall be pleased to give any further details you may desire. A suitable set of scales would be a very desirable addition to the school's equipment.

With best personal wishes, I am,

Yours sincerely,

P. S. Campbell, M. D.

JOHN BROOKS, age 13—Examined April 7, 1930, T. 99, P. 55
R. 20 — 9.45 a.m. Anterior cervical glands enlarged.

Flattening of left chest—Movements retarded—slight dulness—Breathing diminished in lower half, absent at base. Few scattered rales heard to 5 r. and 8 v.s.

Right side nothing special.

X-Ray plate shows marked parenchymatous involvement of left upper lobe with evidence of collapse at base—Thickened pleura.

Rt. side; moderate emphysema with slight parenchymatous changes in upper lobe.

DIAGNOSIS — Pulmonary Tuberculosis.

RECOMMENDATION — A term of Sanatorium treatment.

ADA MACDONALD, age 12—Examined April 7, 1930, T 95, P 50,
R 20 — 11.30 A.M.

Indefinite history of having spat up a small quantity of blood a few months ago. Nutrition good.

On physical examination—nothing definitely abnormal found.

X-Ray plate shows diffuse mottling in left upper lobe in first and second interspaces (anteriorly) which has the appearance of being recent.

Right side — nothing special.

DIAGNOSIS — Pulmonary Tuberculosis.

RECOMMENDATION — A term of Sanatorium treatment.
LOUISE PAUL, age 10.

Examined April 8, 1930, T. 99° F. 98° R. 20, -- 3 p.m.

Discharging right ear.

History of a considerable haemoptysis a few weeks ago.

Physical examination of chest did not reveal a lesion.

X-Ray plate shows some fibrosis of both upper lobes.

Small parenchymatous changes in first and second interspaces left side. Calcified node second interspace left side.

DIAGNOSIS - Min. Pulmonary Tuberculosis.

RECOMMENDATION - A term of Sanatorium treatment.

NICHOLAS DOHERTY, age 9.

Examined April 7, 1930, T. 98° F. 98° R. 20 - 10 a.m.

Personal history negative -- Family history not obtainable.

Nutrition good. One enlarged anterior cervical gland. Breathing diminished at right base. Rales heard right middle lobe and upper part right lower lobe.

X-Ray shows minute parenchymatous infiltration in first and second interspaces on the right side.

Left side, heavy hilum with minute P.C. charges extending out from it in second and third interspaces.

DIAGNOSIS - Pulmonary Tuberculosis.

RECOMMENDATION - A term in Sanatorium.
MARY FICTON, age 18.

Examined April 8, 1930, T. 99.2, P. 24, R. 15 — 6.35 p.m.

At age of eight years had "running sore" in neck—swat up clot of blood four years ago. Mother died of Tuberculosis. Scar on neck resembling scar from old suppurating tuberculous glands.

On physical examination a few dry rales were heard below left clavicle.

X-Ray plates show markedly thickened hili—several calcified nodes in hilar and peri-hilar regions. Slight organized parenchymatous changes in left apex, extending out to periphery in first interspace. Old infiltration, minute, in first and second interspaces, right side.

Two specimens of sputum stained—negative.

DIAGNOSIS — Pulmonary Tuberculosis apparently arrested.

RECOMMENDATION — A rest period of 1½ hours every afternoon (lying down) in a well ventilated room, case to be watched and re-examined from time to time. Another X-Ray plate next year.

GILBERT FRANCIS, age 11.

Examined April 7, 1930, T. 100, P. 92, R. 20 — 10.15 a.m.

History of frequent colds.

Two enlarged anterior cervical glands. No definitely abnormal physical signs found in chest.

X-Ray plates show very heavy left hilum. Scattered calcified nodes right hilum and vicinity.

DIAGNOSIS — Glandular Tuberculosis — Arrested Pulmonary Tuberculosis.

RECOMMENDATION — A daily, two hour rest period, lying down 3.30 — 5.30. Patient to be watched and replated next year.
ELSIE CHARLES, age 13.

Examined April 8, 1930, T. 100, P. 92, R. 20 - 2.15 p.m.

Paternal history of Tuberculosis.

Personal history negative. A well nourished child.

Slight cardiac irregularity—Soft systolic apical murmur heard.

Physical examination of lungs within normal limits.

X-Ray shows old organized parenchymatous changes in second and third interspace right side. Slight beading on left side.

DIAGNOSIS — Min. Pulmonary Tuberculosis arrested.

RECOMMENDATION — An afternoon rest period of 1½ hours.

EDWARD SOCOLIN, age 14.

Examined April 7, 1930, T. 99, P. 76, R. 22 — 10.45 a.m.

Says he put up about two teaspoonfuls of blood over a year ago.

Well nourished.

No definitely abnormal physical signs.

X-Ray shows suggestive of hilar infection. Bronchial markings accentuated both sides—Scattered beading both sides—Suspicious left apex. Diaphragms irregular.

DIAGNOSIS — Suspected Min. Tuberculosis.

RECOMMENDATION — Case to be watched and have follow up.

EXAMINATIONS — Replate next year. An hour afternoon rest desirable.
LUCY BROOKS, age 14.

Examined April 8, 1930, T. 99, P. 74, R. 20 — 11:30 a.m.

History of pneumonia twice.

Spit up a half teaspoonful of blood several weeks ago.

Well nourished.

Breathing quite harsh, especially right side; somewhat diminished at left base.

X-Ray shows diffuse mottling of both upper lobes, particularly in the first interspace right side.

DIAGNOSIS - Questionable minimal Pulmonary Tuberculosis.

RECOMMENDATION - A short period of observation and study at Sanatorium.

JOSEPH JOHN FRANCIS, age 11.

No evidence of Tuberculosis.

You will note that four have been recommended for a period of San. treatment and one for observation and study; ages being 14, 13, 12, 10 and 7 years.

At the Nova Scotia Sanatorium they do not take patients under 12 years of age.

I would suggest that an attempt be made to have the younger patients or for that matter, all of them admitted to the Sanatorium at Lourdes-in-Pictou County, for the summer months. The authorities there might be able to make provision, on the rear balcony, to care for those cases until the autumn at least. If Sanatorium treatment cannot be arranged than the only other alternation, as I see it, is to place the patients on "the cure" in a section of the Shubenacadie School Building. I am not sufficiently familiar with the plan of the building to state whether or not this might be properly done.

I would be strongly opposed to having them sent to their homes.

Ten cases only were X-Rayed and the result surely justified the undertaking.

I would recommend for your serious consideration and for the consideration of the Department of Indian Affairs that all the pupils be X-Rayed for, as you know, the diagnosis of childhood tuberculosis is a difficult matter and justifies the requisition of every possible aid. It is important that open cases of tuberculosis be eliminated, if at all possible, from the new school. We know the Micmac has been well seeded with the bacilli, hence we should endeavour to prevent the conversion of tuberculous infection to tuberculous disease.

In conclusion permit me to refer to the splendid sanitary environment in which the pupils have been placed. I found them well nourished, spotlessly clean and generally well cared for. It is my opinion that those in charge of the institution have brought knowledge, adaptability and resourcefulness to the work.

P. S. Campbell

P. S. Campbell, M. D.,

May 5th, 1930.

Memorandum:

Dr. Stone,

Enclosed is Dr. Campbell's report on his examination of the children at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. This report was received at the school on May 1st and the Principal phoned the sanatorium at Lourdes with a view to having the younger patients admitted there. He was not able to make immediate arrangements owing to the fact that they cannot accommodate additional inmates but they informed him that they would make an endeavour to do so this week. If not successful in this regard, the Principal intends to keep in touch with Dr. Campbell with a view to having his advice regarding what other institution the children could be placed in.

Immediately upon receipt of the report, arrangements were made to give the treatment recommended by Dr. Campbell for those children who were to remain in the school and they were isolated from the other pupils.
Ottawa, May 13th, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

The Department has read, with interest, Dr. Campbell's report regarding his examination of the children at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. It is considered most important in the interests of the health of the others that sanatorium treatment be secured immediately for the four pupils whom Dr. Campbell recommends should receive same. The Department understands that you have already been in communication with the sanatorium at Lourdes and, if you have not yet succeeded in having these four children placed in that institution, I believe that it might be possible to have them placed in the Halifax Tuberculosis Hospital. I trust that you will find it possible to place these children either in the institution mentioned or, if space is not available there, get in touch at once with Dr. Campbell and enlist his co-operation in having them placed.

With reference to the two children who are mentally deficient, the Department has been informed that you are making endeavours to secure accommodation for them in a suitable institution. This action is approved and it is hoped that you will be successful in having them properly cared for.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Rev. J. F. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

May 20th, 1930.

Dear Sir:

Beg to let you know that we had a bad accident in the school yesterday afternoon. About three in the afternoon Brigid Moloney was cleaning the dough mixer and Annie Pennall was working in the kitchen. In some, at the present time unexplainable way, the two of them were caught in the dough mixer. The power switch was turned off; one of them must have set the machine going, how it stopped I don't know. When I got there certainly the power was not on. After things cool down we might be able to get the true explanation. Each girl will probably lose two fingers of the right hand. Needless to say these girls are not youngsters, and they have been warned many times about tinkering with the machines. Today we will put padlocks on every hand-switch in the School.

Of course we took them to the Victoria General Hospital as soon as we could, and they were attended to immediately.

Yours very truly,

A.F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs, Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 28, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, reporting the serious accident to two of the girls, pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, who had their hands caught in the dough mixer. It is noted, with satisfaction, that you have arranged to prevent a similar occurrence in future in the use of machinery operated by electricity at the school.

Dear Sir:

With regard to Ellen Bernard, brought here with four others of the family, by Rev. D.J. Rankin, agent for Victoria County. We find that this child is subject to fits, a series of four fits between 3 p.m. and 9 p.m. on Saturday May 17th, inst., three more early Sunday morning. Had the Doctor over on Saturday night and it is his opinion that nothing really effective can be done.

From what I can learn from other members of the family the Doctor who examined these children was told about this matter, and yet he passed her along. I don't think that it is your intention to have children so afflicted in this school. When these fits take place in the dormitory there is no need of telling you the effect on the other children.

Dear Sir:

As far as the general medical examination which we are to have twice a year, would it be possible to have the first one sometime before the close of school, along about the last of June? Reverend Sir:

I wish to refer to dental work that may be necessary for pupils at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. You may arrange with Dr. Stultz to either do the work in the school or he may take the children to his temporary office in Shubenacadie, whichever is the more convenient. Please explain to him that the Department does not pay the usual office fees in the case of pupils at Indian residential schools. It is expected that very reasonable charges will be secured, as there will no doubt be considerable work necessary from time to time. The Department suggests that only extractions and amalgam fillings be done by Dr. Stultz. Other treatment cannot be authorized. In the case of temporary teeth, extractions only are allowed. July 3rd, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

The Department has received your letter of June 23rd referring to results of examination of the pupils by Doctor MacInnis. With regard to the tonsil work I have to suggest that the matter receive some further consideration. In the first place transportation of the children to and from Halifax will not be without difficulty, and in the second place, you are taking the patients out of the hands of Doctor MacInnis, our local medical officer. You depend upon him for the care of ordinary cases of sickness and accident, and if he is competent to perform the operations himself it appears to the Department that he should be given an opportunity to do so. The first consideration, of course, is that the work should be done by a thoroughly competent man. The removal of tonsils from a large number of children is a fairly grave responsibility. You, as a resident of the district, may be expected to be familiar with the qualifications of Doctor MacInnis, and the Department will be pleased to receive your opinion on this matter and to keep it confidential. In any case the subject should be candidly discussed between you and the Doctor so that there may be no misunderstanding.

While the Department has an arrangement with the Victoria General Hospital to care for cases of sickness at the rate of $3.00 per day, including the fees of the Doctor, it is quite possible that the hospital may not be willing to have a large number of tonsil cases admitted under this arrangement. If you decide to advise the Department to have the patients sent to Halifax, it would be best for you to make a visit to the hospital and see what arrangements can be made in case the hospital authorities

Rev. J.D. Mackey,
Principal, Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.
decline to accept these pupils under the inclusive arrangement.

If you think Doctor MacInnis can fulfill the requirements you might ascertain from him what his total fee would be for carrying out the operations. The Department usually obtains a substantial reduction in the case of a large number of operations, and it is suggested that the fee of $20.00 per pupil should include the fees of the Anaesthetist and of a surgical nurse who should be retained during the progress of the work. Not more than 8 cases should be done on any one day.

The Department also wishes to be assured that the removal of tonsils from so many pupils is strictly required for the improvement of the health of each child concerned, and in this connection would appreciate an additional examination by Doctor MacInnis and the Doctor whom he calls in to assist him.

With regard to the optical work, it would be appreciated if you would submit the name of the Oculist or Optician whom you wish to employ.

Your obedient servant,

A.F. MacKenzie,

July 8th, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

The Department has received your letter of July 3rd reporting the admission to sanatorium of Ada MacDonald and Lucy Brooks. It is very satisfactory that you have been able to find accommodation for these children, and it will not be necessary for you to take further trouble with them as they are no longer school pupils.

It may possibly be advisable to restate the Department's views in regard to these tuberculous children. It is the policy of the Department to keep your school tuberculosis free, and in pursuance of that policy the essential feature is to prevent the entrance to the school of tuberculous children, and to remove from the school as soon as possible any who are found to have developed the disease. The disposition of the sick children is not the first consideration. If no other means can be found to care for them, they must be sent back to their reserves even though this course seems hard on them. In such a case they are no worse off than if they had not come to the school.

The Department is assured that you understand this point of view which has a bearing on the other tuberculous children whose removal you have not yet reported.

Your obedient servant,

Sept. 11th, 1930

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of Sept. 5th inst., I would like you to consider this letter as confidential. I have at least once in the past refused to sign the vouchers of Dr. McInnis.

As for the tonsils I talked the matter over with the Doctor and in fact he read the letters of July 3rd and 25th. During the time of the operations figured it out that should he take the fee of $20.00 for each case, he would make more money than he would by that provided in your letter of July 25th. I felt then that there would be trouble but it was too late then to halt matters.

For my own part, two of the Sisters including the nurse were called to Halifax for their annual retreat of ten days. I saw immediately that with over ninety children in the house, we could not give the necessary attention. Besides that I was nervous about leaving the children with anyone who was not a nurse, especially immediately after they left the operating room. Therefore I engaged two nurses. Dr. J.B. Reid brought a nurse with him for the to assist in the operating room. My sister arrived the same day, and since she is a graduate nurse I put her to work also. So in all we had two Doctors and four nurses, one in with the doctors, two to attend the children immediately before and after
the operation. The two nurses I engaged were on duty day and night. My sister relieving for them. These nurses were kept busy from Tuesday morning till the following Sunday when they returned to Halifax. I paid them $25.00 each from the School funds and charged it up to extra labor. The nurse Dr. Reid brought with him was on duty only during the actual time of operating, three days.

Now the way the Doctor worked it out was this: 31 cases at $20.00 gives $620.00 For Dr. Reid $300.00 Nurses at $5.00 a day $65.00 Himself $155.00 Balance $100.00 to be divided between himself and Dr. Reid.

When I heard that I made up my mind that I would take the money coming to the two nurses I had engaged and return the fifty dollars to the School fund. Otherwise I felt that there would be so much more to divide and I think I know where the larger share would go. I must say that Dr. Reid seemed quite satisfied to accept what the Dept. had stipulated.

My suggestion is that is that you pay Dr. McInnis five dollars a case $185.00 Dr. Reid $300.00 The operating room nurse I think should receive $6.00 a day or $18.00 for her share of the work. If you could include the nurses share with Dr. Reid it would be convenient, as she works with him a good deal. I don't know her name. We should like reimbursement for the dinners, mid-afternoon lunches and my cigarettes. If I were as grasping as some people I would mean that.

Yours very truly,

Ottawa, October 9, 1930.

Mr. Ferris,

With reference to your memorandum of August 26, last, should the services of a dentist be required for the pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian residential school, Dr. Karl K. Dimock, of Windsor, may be employed.

Acting D. S. C. I. A.
Ottawa, October 10, 1930.

Reverend Sir:

With reference to earlier correspondence concerning a dentist for the pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, I have now to authorize you to offer the work to Dr. Karl K. Dimock, of Windsor. Please inform him that there should be two visits to the school per annum and that the teeth of all children should be examined. No fee will be allowed for the examination, but he will be allowed $1.00 per amalgam filling and 25¢ per extraction. No prophylactic or other treatment is authorized, and, in the case of temporary teeth extraction only is desired.

If Dr. Dimock accepts this proposition, have him come to the school for his first work at his earliest convenience. The Department expects you to provide him with board and room while he is engaged with the pupils.

If this arrangement is confirmed, other dental services should not be engaged, except, of course, in real emergencies. You could not expect Dr. Dimock to come to the school for a small amount of work; and if you find it convenient to take a pupil or two to his office, the Department will allow $1.50 per filling and 50¢ per extraction. These fees, however, are only in the case of one or two pupils. All necessary work should be done when he is making his semi-annual visit to the school.

I am enclosing an extra copy of this communication, in the event that you wish to leave it with Dr. Dimock for his guidance.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of Oct 1st received and contents noted. Your prices offered are contemptible. You must be taking me for a fool.

Any Medical Man who has a good General Practice will certainly lose all interest in Government and Indian Work when he is paid such prices. Those are the prices paid any ordinary labourer. Place them before any Medical Man.

Oct 6th 1930
in any part of Canada and get their opinion on it.

After finishing with the tonsil cases I paid the surgeon (Mr. Murray Gordon) who assisted us in the operating room $15.00 out of my own pocket and got a receipt for it.

I had to take down my operating table and set it up at the school and then go after it and take it down and bring it home again. I had to make a visit to the school each day we operated which I didn't include in the bill and would amount to $4.00. Also in regard to vaccinations, if I am not paid for a call to the school the Principal in the future must bear them.
Dr. D. F. MacInnis

Shubenacadie, N.S.

Conveyed to my office.

In the future any operative throat cases or any cases where I require an assistant must go to the Hospital as I am not going to give anaesthetics for $5.00, or do operation work at your prices.

Please add the $5.00 paid Mrs. Gordon to my account, along with the $2.00 for visits.

Yours sincerely,

D.F.M. MacInnis

Reverend Sir,

You will find enclosed copy of a letter dated October 1st written to Dr. McInnis in reference to his account for the month of August which includes the charges for the tonsil operations done for the school during that month. In reply to this letter Dr. McInnis among other things states that the Department has been very unfair in offering him the fee paid for giving the anaesthetics. He further states that unless he is paid a fee for visiting the school to vaccinate the pupils, in addition to that for the vaccination, it will be necessary for you to parade the pupils to his office. There should not be any hardship either for you or the children in this connection, and there does not seem to be any reason why he should have to come to the school for this purpose. He says that he paid Mrs. Yeadon, a nurse, $15.00 for her services. If you will take a receipt from Dr. McInnis for this payment the Department will send him a cheque in your care. Kindly send this receipt to the Department at your earliest convenience.

Your obedient servant,

Shubenacadie, N.S.

LD
October 14th, 1930.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of October 6th referring to payments made to you for professional services rendered to the pupils of the Shubenacadie Residential School in the month of August, I have to advise you that the Department has no intention of re-considering its decision.

With regard to the fees for anaesthetics given by you, you were paid precisely what the Department offered and what you presumably undertook the work for. The fee of $5.00 for an anaesthetic for tonsil operation is that paid by the Department everywhere in Canada and accepted without complaint. It might well appear that a Doctor is not ill paid in earning $155.00 for three days work, which can by no means be considered of a special nature and which was carried out within a very short distance of his office.

With regard to the fee for vaccination it is noted that you were paid for a visit to the school on August 12th and for vaccination of twenty-one pupils on the same day. There is no reason why you should have to visit the school for vaccinating pupils and the Principal is being advised of this fact.

Dear Sir;

Have made inquiries concerning the home conditions of Ellen Francis, the only active T.B. Child we have in the School, and find that the conditions are very bad. This being the case I judged from your letter that you would be willing to have her go to the Sanatorium. Ada MacDonald at present at the San. is about ready to come back and therefore I made the arrangements to take Ellen Francis down and bring Ada MacDonald back, making the one trip do. We expect to have the transfer made this week.

Hoping that this will meet with your approval.

Dear Sir:

Your proposition re dental work for the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie has been sent me by the Rev. J. P. Mackey, Principal of that school.

I notice by your letter that there has been no provision made for the case of anterior teeth, which it seems to me would be equally if not more important than the posterior. Therefore, I am drawing your attention to this matter and hope you will make arrangements to allow me One Dollar Fifty Cents ($1.50) per white enamel filling.

In regard to extractions
the Department could not expect a dentist to extract teeth for twenty-five Cents (25¢) and use the humane methods in vogue today. This should be at least Fifty Cents (50¢) per extraction.

It was my privilege to do considerable work among soldiers and returned men for the government, and I would say that the fees were substantially above those quoted in this letter. Trusting you will give this your consideration and be able to meet me as to prices.

Your obedient servant,

Two things struck me rather forcibly on this my second visit to the school for purposes of chest examining the pupils, and roughly five and one half months after my first visit: firstly the improved nutritional and general appearance of those who were there in April and secondly the definite improvement in those whose rest treatment had been advised in April.

It would seem that the Micmac children respond to the hygienic life which is, after all, the treatment for tuberculosis. The marked change from generally poor home living conditions, nearly ideal environment of the school, is apparently having effect. It will be interesting to watch this over a period of time and to note the ultimate result.

In the light of evidence obtainable it would appear that average case of closed tuberculosis will do just as well at the school as at any tuberculosis institution. Of course I do not keep open cases there; all such should be removed to institutions or at least isolated.

I wish again to comment favourably on the efficient manner in which the pupils are being cared for at the school.

P.S. Campbell, M.D.,

Ottawa, October 29, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to dental work for the pupils at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. The Department will allow $1.50 for white enamel fillings in the case of anterior teeth and 50¢ for extractions of permanent teeth. The rate for ordinary amalgam fillings will be $1.00 and extractions in the case of temporary teeth, 25¢. These are the fees that are allowed at other Indian residential schools in Canada. It is true that they are substantially less than those for soldiers and returned men; but the Department feels that wholesale rates should be allowed for school children in residence.

If you accept this proposal, please inform Father Mackey, and you may make your first visit to the school at your earliest convenience. Father Mackey is receiving a copy of this letter to you.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, November 8, 1930.

Rev. Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of the account which you forwarded from Dr. A. R. Cunningham, Halifax, covering his charges for the examining and testing of eyes and supplying of glasses for 17 pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. This account is returned herewith, as it is considered the fees charged for examining and testing of eyes are rather high. I may say that the fees paid by the Department in other cases have been approximately $5 for examination and prescription, and from $5 to $8 for each pair of glasses, depending upon the power of the lenses supplied.

It is thought that the account of Dr. Cunningham should be amended accordingly, and a detailed statement furnished giving the names of the pupils who were supplied with glasses and the fee for the examination and cost of glasses for each pupil. Please refer this matter to Dr. Cunningham at an early date, and endeavour to have him render an account at a much lower rate than that charged in the account which is being returned.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Dear Sir:

In the enclosed account I notice that there is a visit to Ellen Francis, with charge of $2.00. All that Dr. MacInnis had to do with this case was to sign a couple of papers in order to clear the way for the Sanatorium. He brought the papers over to me and no doubt that is the visit.

As we had a few with sore throats I thought it would be alright to have the semi-annual examination. The first exam only covered about ninety children. The result of the examination is that there are twenty-two to have their tonsils out. A few of these are urgent.

Would it be advisable to take these MacDonald children to the V.G. Hospital and have them examined to see whether there are any of this syphilis left. It strikes me that their treatment is continuing a very long time?

November 22nd, 1930.

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of the 7th instant together with account of Dr. D.F. MacInnis.

I note what you say regarding the tonsil operations required, but the Department is not prepared to authorize any save the most urgent of these. Please inform me as to the number of such cases.

Regarding the duration of treatment required by the MacDonald children, you should rely on the judgment of Doctor MacInnes, who will doubtless take samples of their blood from time to time to be tested. No idea can be given of the probable duration of this treatment, but it is necessary that it should be carried to a proper conclusion.

Your obedient servant,

November 26th, 1930.

Dear Sir,

An Indian child, named Mary Brooks, was admitted to your Hospital, on October 7th, from the Residential School at Shubenacadie. The report from the School stated that she had gonorrhoea, but the hospital account gives a diagnosis of syphilis. It would be appreciated if the doctor in charge of her case would give this Department a professional report on her present condition, and indicate whether she might safely be returned to school for completion of treatment.

If she has both diseases she should not be discharged from the Hospital until the gonorrhoea is cured and, in any case, she should not be discharged in an infectious condition. Facilities are available at the School for the treatment of syphilis, if the patient is not a menace to the other pupils.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

Yours truly,

Some how we missed one boy and there was one girl who had a cured T.B. jaw and the Dentist was afraid to extract on account of the weakened appearance of the jaw bone. MEMORANDUM

Honourable Thomas G. Murphy,

With reference to the attached letter from Mr. Quinn concerning Dr. Cunningham's account, I may say that the Doctor was engaged to test the eyes and supply glasses for seventeen pupils at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. It was requested that inexpensive mountings and lenses should be supplied.

Dr. Cunningham rendered an account for $265.00 which seemed high to our officers, and it was returned to the Principal with the request for a much lower rate. The word "Exorbitant" was not used in the correspondence.

The Department is accustomed to secure special prices for these services when a number of pupils are treated. I presume that the work was done in a single day and that the Doctor drove a total of ninety miles. Therefore, I consider $10.00 per pupil, or $170.00, plus $10.00 for expenses will be a fair fee.

Memorandum,

DOCTOR SCOTT:

Five pupils of the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia, are certified by the Medical Officer to require immediate removal of tonsils. Authority was given to have the work done at Victoria General Hospital, Halifax, but the Principal informs the Department that that hospital cannot receive them until after March 1st next. He asks permission to have the work done at another hospital, name not stated, for a sum not exceeding $15.00 each. The hospital he refers to is probably Truro, but objection was taken to the employment of Doctor Reid of that place on a former occasion. The Principal wants to get the work done during the Christmas holidays, but we do not know who is to be employed. Shall we take him at his word and leave the matter open for him to get the work done at the sum stated, which is very reasonable?

E.L. Stone, M.B.

February 21st, 1931.

Dear Father Mackey,

I note from your latest Nurse's report that you have had chickenpox at the school. Now chickenpox is a relatively harmless disease, but one of the worst epidemics of smallpox in recent years gained headway because it was diagnosed as chickenpox, and the people in charge did not support themselves by getting the opinion of another Doctor. Since that time I have been nervous about chickenpox. This is one of the reasons why the Department instructs those in charge of Indians to report epidemics of any kind by telegram within twelve hours. I do not suppose you could have an epidemic of smallpox, as your children are thoroughly vaccinated, but I want to take this opportunity of drawing to your attention the importance of reporting any kind of communicable disease. Circular 93-1 is worthy of careful study by everyone.

I think you are to be congratulated on the good health at your school. It often happens that a new school has a run of bad health for the first year or two but you seem to have escaped. Let us hope that you will continue to be fortunate.

Yours truly,

E.L. Stone, M.B.
Director of Medical Services

Rev. J.P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

Dear Sir:

Fred Nash No. 71 has very poor eye-sight. To read he must hold the book within three inches of his eyes, and it is impossible for him to copy any work from the black-board. He is industrious enough and wants to get along. He was not here at the time Dr. Cunningham did the eye work. I honestly believe that it would be worth while to do something for this boy.

After the experience with Dr. Cunningham I do not feel like making any recommendations. Will you please let me know what you think about it.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, March 16, 1931.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 6th instant, relative to the case of pupil No. 71, Fred Nash, who requires to have his eyes examined and glasses supplied.

In reply I have to say that, on the occasion of a member of the staff of the school travelling to Halifax, this boy could be taken to Dr. Cunningham to have his eyes examined and the glasses required supplied him. It is considered that spectacles with flat lenses and an inexpensive frame would be satisfactory. An account covering the fees charged for the examination and for the glasses should be forwarded, in duplicate, properly certified by yourself, covering the expenditure incurred.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Right side dull. Breathing bronchial at apex. Whispered sound increased at apex. Roles heard to fourth rib and fifth dorsal spine.

Right sided Pleurisy which I take to be of a tuberculous nature.

No. 51-0-13

Dear Sir:

Enclosed you will find the results of Dr. Campbell's recent examination of the children who have come to the School since October last, and a few who have been under observation for the past year.

As you will see Christina Pennall is an acute case of T.B. A year ago there was no sign of T.B. Dr. Campbell called the Sanatorium but they could not take her immediately, but gave us some hope that they might take her in ten days or two weeks time. Her father is dead and her mother is working in Halifax and living with a married daughter. Under those circumstances I hope it will be alright to send her to the Sanatorium, and will do so unless I hear the contrary from you.

The other case of John Bernard in the opinion of Dr. Kelmis will after a time come along alright. After Dr. Campbell's examination of him there were other things came to light which seemed to indicate that his condition was not so bad.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum,

MR. WILLIAMS:

With reference to the attached telegram, I have to report as follows:

Mr. Foster must be misinformed as to surgical work done at the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, during the week ending November 22nd. A special report has been secured by telegram from the Reverend Principal, and the only work done during that week was dental service carried out by a Doctor Dimmock, of Windsor.

In the month of September, Doctor McInnes, the authorized Medical Attendant at the School, held a clinic at which the tonsils of 31 pupils were removed. This was done under instructions issued to the Principal in July. The work was delayed until the pupils re-assembled after the summer vacation. Doctor McInnes required the assistance of a surgeon, and called in Doctor Reid, of Truro. The Department gave him no instructions as to who should be engaged. Doctor Reid is not a regular employee.

Doctor McInnes is employed on the Account System to attend the pupils of the School, and on salary as follows:

For Elmsdale, Wellington vicinity (Halifax and Hants Counties) $200.00 per annum
Shubenacadie & vicinity (Hants County) $250.00 per annum with allowance of $100.00 for drugs. This appointment was made by the Civil Service Commission in 1919. The other appointments were not made by the Commission.

The Department is informed that Doctor McInnes is the only Doctor at Shubenacadie, or near enough to give satisfactory attendance to the School. His professional capacity has never been questioned, but he is a difficult man to get along with from a business standpoint, and his position as the only available medical man seems to make him very independent. At different times he has stated that he would not continue to attend the Indians at Elmsdale and Wellington unless he were paid more salary. Any increase over the $200 now paid for this work would bring the position under the Civil Service Commission. There are Doctors at Bedford, at about the same distance from Elmsdale and Wellington as Doctor McInnes is. One of them is an elderly man, but the Department understands that the other, Doctor Granville, might be willing to take over this work at the salary now paid Doctor McInnes.

The work done at the School in September cost as follows:

Doctor McInnes - for anaesthetics $155.00
Doctor Reid - for surgical work $300.00

$455.00

It is stated that there is more work of the same kind to be done, but funds are not available to carry it out. I am not aware whether Doctor Reid would be acceptable now. If not, I might ask you whom the Principal should be instructed to engage in future.

E.L. Stone, M.B.
Director of Medical Services

June 6th, 1931.

Dear Sir:

Beg to inform you that we have sent Mary Cremo No. 619 to the V.G. Hospital. On the advise of Dr. McInnis we took her to Halifax, to Dr. Davis, an optician. He in turn said to take her to Mathers & Doul, medical opticians. This child has ulcers on the eye. As this would require treatment for some time, which we could not obtain here, without seeing Mathers & Doul I had her placed in the hospital. It was the best I could do under the circumstances, as I was a patient in the Halifax Infirmary at the time for a septum operation.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

June 10th, 1931.

Reverend Sir,

I have your letter of June 1st regarding John Bernard, a tuberculous Indian pupil of your school.

In accordance with Circular 450-3, copy of which is herewith enclosed, I am unable to authorize sanatorium treatment. Dr. McInnis has diagnosed this case as pulmonary tuberculosis, and it is not considered that an X-Ray examination now would be of any benefit, in view of the fact that funds are not available to meet the cost of subsequent hospitalization.

Dr. McInnis is probably in the best position to consider the advisability of this boy remaining in school under the care of your infirmary, or whether home treatment would be more feasible. The Department is willing to leave it to you and Dr. McInnis to make the most economical arrangement possible under the circumstances.

It is intended that you should continue to report each case to the Department as you have done in this instance.

Yours truly,

Rev. J. P. Mackey,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

August 10th, 1931.

Dear Miss Murdoch,

I have your letter of July 25th together with reports of Red Sand Reserve.

I observe that Mr. Hudson would like to have you accompany a group of children from his Agency to Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. This authorizes you to make the trip proposed, as the Medical Branch has made an arrangement with the Schools Branch in this connection.

I regret that it has not been possible to establish a field matron position in Prince Edward Island as you recommended, but the matter has been kept in mind.

Yours truly,

Dear Dr. Stone,

Another matter I would like to mention is the daily routine of children transferred from Sanatoria to Shubenacadie. Should these children not have a rest period in the afternoons and not be subjected to strenuous labor? Esther Phillips has returned from the school. Her family (at Woodstock) are always in great trouble you will remember, so allowances should be made. Her mother complained that Esther had to work hard all the time, did not have any rest period during the day but at play time had to go out and romp instead of resting and that she was punished by having to stand at night for several hours - of course this may all be greatly exaggerated.

Yours very sincerely,

(Sgd) Mary L. Murdoch
